abstract.p: Letter from William L Minnix Jr (American Assn of Homes and Services for the Aging) comments on problem of providing rental housing for low-income elderly (Feb 15 article); notes Pres Bush has proposed cutting by nearly $200 million the federal program that provides for both construction and rent subsidies for low-income elderly

block.p: ''Hot Niche in the Rental Market: Housing for the Elderly'' (Business Day, Feb. 15) focused on the investment potential of this housing but missed the main point: our population is aging, and older adults need a place to live.
As noted, there are many options for people with money, but what about people who cannot afford a $399,000 entry fee or $6,000 monthly maintenance costs?

''Hot Niche in the Rental Market: Housing for the Elderly'' (Business Day, Feb. 15) focused on the investment potential of this housing but missed the main point: our population is aging, and older adults need a place to live.
As noted, there are many options for people with money, but what about people who cannot afford a $399,000 entry fee or $6,000 monthly maintenance costs?

President Bush has proposed cutting by nearly $200 million the federal program that provides for both construction and rent subsidies for low-income elderly. The remaining funds would provide an average of 54 new units per state at a time when there are nine people on the waiting list for every available unit.
Many affordable housing communities provide services like meals and transportation, helping residents avoid premature institutional care. That's a good investment.
William L. Minnix Jr. Washington, Feb. 16, 2006
The writer is chief executive of the American Association of Homes and Services for the Aging.
